choicesHtml: In the mid-twentieth century, Africans highlighted the complexity of ancient African societies to advocate for citizenship in European countries.
In the years immediately before this conference, college students participated in the Black Campus movement, demanding culturally relevant learning opportunities.
In the years just after this conference, the Second World Black Festival of Arts and Culture (FESTAC) angered West Africans by rejecting a proposal to honor Queen Idia of Benin.
During the 1960s and 1970s, African American enrollment in United States colleges and universities declined rapidly as young people focused on the Civil Rights movement instead.
